trans-unit.source: How to use the Xamarin Component client | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use the Xamarin Component client | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Xamarin Component client for Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Xamarin Component client for Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: How to use the Xamarin Component client for Azure Mobile Services
trans-unit.target: How to use the Xamarin Component client for Azure Mobile Services

trans-unit.source: This guide shows you how to perform common scenarios using the Xamarin Component client for Azure Mobile Services, in Xamarin apps for iOS and Android.
trans-unit.target: This guide shows you how to perform common scenarios using the Xamarin Component client for Azure Mobile Services, in Xamarin apps for iOS and Android.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include querying for data, inserting, updating, and deleting data, authenticating users, and handling errors.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include querying for data, inserting, updating, and deleting data, authenticating users, and handling errors.

trans-unit.source: If you are new to Mobile Services, you should consider first completing the "Mobile Services quickstart" tutorial ([Xamarin.iOS][Xamarin.iOS quickstart tutorial]/[Xamarin.Android][Xamarin.Android quickstart tutorial]) and the "Getting Started with Data in .NET" tutorial ([Xamarin.iOS][Xamarin.iOS data tutorial]/[Xamarin.Android][Xamarin.Android data tutorial]).
trans-unit.target: If you are new to Mobile Services, you should consider first completing the "Mobile Services quickstart" tutorial ([Xamarin.iOS][Xamarin.iOS quickstart tutorial]/[Xamarin.Android][Xamarin.Android quickstart tutorial]) and the "Getting Started with Data in .NET" tutorial ([Xamarin.iOS][Xamarin.iOS data tutorial]/[Xamarin.Android][Xamarin.Android data tutorial]).

trans-unit.source: The quickstart tutorial requires [Xamarin][Xamarin download] the [Mobile Services SDK] and helps you configure your account and create your first mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The quickstart tutorial requires [Xamarin][Xamarin download] the [Mobile Services SDK] and helps you configure your account and create your first mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Setup and Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Setup and Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: We assume that you have created a mobile service and a table.
trans-unit.target: We assume that you have created a mobile service and a table.

trans-unit.source: For more information see [Create a table](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=298592).
trans-unit.target: For more information see [Create a table](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=298592).

trans-unit.source: In the code used in this topic, the table is named `TodoItem` and it will have the following columns: `id`, `Text`, and `Complete`.
trans-unit.target: In the code used in this topic, the table is named `TodoItem` and it will have the following columns: `id`, `Text`, and `Complete`.

trans-unit.source: The corresponding typed client-side .NET type is the following:
trans-unit.target: The corresponding typed client-side .NET type is the following:

trans-unit.source: When dynamic schema is enabled, Azure Mobile Services automatically generates new columns based on the object in insert or update requests.
trans-unit.target: When dynamic schema is enabled, Azure Mobile Services automatically generates new columns based on the object in insert or update requests.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Dynamic schema](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=296271).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Dynamic schema](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=296271).

trans-unit.source: How to: Create the Mobile Services client
trans-unit.target: How to: Create the Mobile Services client

trans-unit.source: The following code creates the `MobileServiceClient` object that is used to access your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates the `MobileServiceClient` object that is used to access your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: In the code above, replace `AppUrl` and `AppKey` with the mobile service URL and application key, in that order.
trans-unit.target: In the code above, replace `AppUrl` and `AppKey` with the mobile service URL and application key, in that order.

trans-unit.source: Both of these are available on the Azure Management Portal, by selecting your mobile service and then clicking on "Dashboard".
trans-unit.target: Both of these are available on the Azure Management Portal, by selecting your mobile service and then clicking on "Dashboard".

trans-unit.source: How to: Create a table reference
trans-unit.target: How to: Create a table reference

trans-unit.source: All of the code that accesses or modifies data in the Mobile Services table calls functions on the `MobileServiceTable` object.
trans-unit.target: All of the code that accesses or modifies data in the Mobile Services table calls functions on the `MobileServiceTable` object.

trans-unit.source: You get a reference to the table by calling the [GetTable](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/jj554275.aspx) function on an instance of the `MobileServiceClient`.
trans-unit.target: You get a reference to the table by calling the [GetTable](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/jj554275.aspx) function on an instance of the `MobileServiceClient`.

trans-unit.source: This is the typed serialization model; see discussion of the untyped serialization model below.
trans-unit.target: This is the typed serialization model; see discussion of the untyped serialization model below.

trans-unit.source: How to: Query data from a mobile service
trans-unit.target: How to: Query data from a mobile service

trans-unit.source: This section describes how to issue queries to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This section describes how to issue queries to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Subsections describe different aspects such as sorting, filtering, and paging.
trans-unit.target: Subsections describe different aspects such as sorting, filtering, and paging.

trans-unit.source: How to: Filter returned data
trans-unit.target: How to: Filter returned data

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to filter data by including a `Where` clause in a query.
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to filter data by including a `Where` clause in a query.

trans-unit.source: It returns all items from `todoTable` whose `Complete` property is equal to `false`.
trans-unit.target: It returns all items from `todoTable` whose `Complete` property is equal to `false`.

trans-unit.source: The `Where` function applies a row filtering predicate to the query against the table.
trans-unit.target: The `Where` function applies a row filtering predicate to the query against the table.

trans-unit.source: You can view the URI of the request sent to the mobile service by using message inspection software, such as browser developer tools or Fiddler.
trans-unit.target: You can view the URI of the request sent to the mobile service by using message inspection software, such as browser developer tools or Fiddler.

trans-unit.source: If you look at the request URI below, notice that we are modifying the query string itself:
trans-unit.target: If you look at the request URI below, notice that we are modifying the query string itself:

trans-unit.source: This request would normally be translated roughly into the following SQL query on the server side:
trans-unit.target: This request would normally be translated roughly into the following SQL query on the server side:

trans-unit.source: The function which is passed to the `Where` method can have an arbitrary number of conditions.
trans-unit.target: The function which is passed to the `Where` method can have an arbitrary number of conditions.

trans-unit.source: For example, the line below:
trans-unit.target: For example, the line below:

trans-unit.source: Would be roughly translated (for the same request shown before) as
trans-unit.target: Would be roughly translated (for the same request shown before) as

trans-unit.source: The `where` statement above will find items with `Complete` status set to false with non-null `Text`.
trans-unit.target: The `where` statement above will find items with `Complete` status set to false with non-null `Text`.

trans-unit.source: We also could have written that in multiple lines instead:
trans-unit.target: We also could have written that in multiple lines instead:

trans-unit.source: The two methods are equivalent and may be used interchangeably.
trans-unit.target: The two methods are equivalent and may be used interchangeably.

trans-unit.source: The former option -- of concatenating multiple predicates in one query -- is more compact and recommended.
trans-unit.target: The former option -- of concatenating multiple predicates in one query -- is more compact and recommended.

trans-unit.source: The `where` clause supports operations that be translated into the Mobile Services OData subset.
trans-unit.target: The `where` clause supports operations that be translated into the Mobile Services OData subset.

trans-unit.source: This includes relational operators (==, !=, <, <=, >, >=), arithmetic operators (+, -, /, *, %), number precision (Math.Floor, Math.Ceiling), string functions (Length, Substring, Replace, IndexOf, StartsWith, EndsWith), date properties (Year, Month, Day, Hour, Minute, Second), access properties of an object, and expressions combining all of these.
trans-unit.target: This includes relational operators (==, !=, <, <=, >, >=), arithmetic operators (+, -, /, *, %), number precision (Math.Floor, Math.Ceiling), string functions (Length, Substring, Replace, IndexOf, StartsWith, EndsWith), date properties (Year, Month, Day, Hour, Minute, Second), access properties of an object, and expressions combining all of these.

trans-unit.source: How to: Sort returned data
trans-unit.target: How to: Sort returned data

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to sort data by including an `OrderBy` or `OrderByDescending` function in the query.
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to sort data by including an `OrderBy` or `OrderByDescending` function in the query.

trans-unit.source: It returns items from `todoTable` sorted ascending by the `Text` field.
trans-unit.target: It returns items from `todoTable` sorted ascending by the `Text` field.

trans-unit.source: By default, the server returns only the first 50 elements.
trans-unit.target: By default, the server returns only the first 50 elements.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] A server-driven page size is used by default to prevent all elements from being returned.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] A server-driven page size is used by default to prevent all elements from being returned.

trans-unit.source: This keeps default requests for large data sets from negatively impacting the service.
trans-unit.target: This keeps default requests for large data sets from negatively impacting the service.

trans-unit.source: You may increase the number of items to be returned by calling `Take` as described in the next section.
trans-unit.target: You may increase the number of items to be returned by calling `Take` as described in the next section.

trans-unit.source: How to: Return data in pages
trans-unit.target: How to: Return data in pages

trans-unit.source: The following code shows how to implement paging in returned data by using the `Take` and `Skip` clauses in the query.
trans-unit.target: The following code shows how to implement paging in returned data by using the `Take` and `Skip` clauses in the query.

trans-unit.source: The following query, when executed, returns the top three items in the table.
trans-unit.target: The following query, when executed, returns the top three items in the table.

trans-unit.source: The following revised query skips the first three results and returns the next three after that.
trans-unit.target: The following revised query skips the first three results and returns the next three after that.

trans-unit.source: This is effectively the second "page" of data, where the page size is three items.
trans-unit.target: This is effectively the second "page" of data, where the page size is three items.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the [IncludeTotalCount](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/jj730933.aspx) method to ensure that the query will get the total count for all the records that would have been returned, ignoring any take paging/limit clause specified:
trans-unit.target: You can also use the [IncludeTotalCount](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/jj730933.aspx) method to ensure that the query will get the total count for all the records that would have been returned, ignoring any take paging/limit clause specified:

trans-unit.source: This is a simplified scenario of passing hard-coded paging values to the `Take` and `Skip` methods.
trans-unit.target: This is a simplified scenario of passing hard-coded paging values to the `Take` and `Skip` methods.

trans-unit.source: In a real-world app, you can use queries similar to the above with a pager control or comparable UI to let users navigate to previous and next pages.
trans-unit.target: In a real-world app, you can use queries similar to the above with a pager control or comparable UI to let users navigate to previous and next pages.

trans-unit.source: How to: Select specific columns
trans-unit.target: How to: Select specific columns

trans-unit.source: You can specify which set of properties to include in the results by adding a `Select` clause to your query.
trans-unit.target: You can specify which set of properties to include in the results by adding a `Select` clause to your query.

trans-unit.target: For example, the following code shows how to select just one field and also how to select and format multiple fields:

trans-unit.target: All the functions described so far are additive, so we can just keep calling them and we'll each time affect more of the query.

trans-unit.target: One more example:

trans-unit.source: How to: Look up data by ID
trans-unit.target: How to: Look up data by ID

trans-unit.source: The `LookupAsync` function can be used to look up objects from the database with a particular ID.
trans-unit.target: The `LookupAsync` function can be used to look up objects from the database with a particular ID.

trans-unit.source: How to: Insert data into a mobile service
trans-unit.target: How to: Insert data into a mobile service

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to perform insert, lookup, delete, or update operations on a type, then you need to create a member called **Id** (regardless of case).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to perform insert, lookup, delete, or update operations on a type, then you need to create a member called **Id** (regardless of case).

trans-unit.source: This is why the example class **TodoItem** has a member of name **Id**.
trans-unit.target: This is why the example class **TodoItem** has a member of name **Id**.

trans-unit.source: An ID value must not be set to anything other than the default value during insert operations; by contrast, the ID value should always be set to a non-default value and present in update and delete operations.
trans-unit.target: An ID value must not be set to anything other than the default value during insert operations; by contrast, the ID value should always be set to a non-default value and present in update and delete operations.

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to insert new rows into a table.
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to insert new rows into a table.

trans-unit.source: The parameter contains the data to be inserted as a .NET object.
trans-unit.target: The parameter contains the data to be inserted as a .NET object.

trans-unit.source: After the await `todoTable.InsertAsync` call returns, the ID of the object in the server is populated to the `todoItem` object in the client.
trans-unit.target: After the await `todoTable.InsertAsync` call returns, the ID of the object in the server is populated to the `todoItem` object in the client.

trans-unit.source: To insert untyped data, you may take advantage of Json.NET as shown below.
trans-unit.target: To insert untyped data, you may take advantage of Json.NET as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Again, note that an ID must not be specified when inserting an object.
trans-unit.target: Again, note that an ID must not be specified when inserting an object.

trans-unit.source: If you attempt to insert an item with the "Id" field already set, you will get back a `MobileServiceInvalidOperationException` from the service.
trans-unit.target: If you attempt to insert an item with the "Id" field already set, you will get back a `MobileServiceInvalidOperationException` from the service.

trans-unit.source: How to: Modify data in a mobile service
trans-unit.target: How to: Modify data in a mobile service

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to update an existing instance with the same ID with new information.
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to update an existing instance with the same ID with new information.

trans-unit.source: The parameter contains the data to be updated as a .NET object.
trans-unit.target: The parameter contains the data to be updated as a .NET object.

trans-unit.source: To insert untyped data, you may take advantage of Json.NET like so.
trans-unit.target: To insert untyped data, you may take advantage of Json.NET like so.

trans-unit.source: Note that when making an update, an ID must be specified, as that is how the mobile service identifies which instance to update.
trans-unit.target: Note that when making an update, an ID must be specified, as that is how the mobile service identifies which instance to update.

trans-unit.source: The ID can be obtained from the result of the `InsertAsync` call.
trans-unit.target: The ID can be obtained from the result of the `InsertAsync` call.

trans-unit.source: If you attempt to update an item without the "Id" field already set, there is no way for the service to tell which instance to update, so you will get back a `MobileServiceInvalidOperationException` from the service.
trans-unit.target: If you attempt to update an item without the "Id" field already set, there is no way for the service to tell which instance to update, so you will get back a `MobileServiceInvalidOperationException` from the service.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, if you attempt to update an untyped item without the "Id" field already set, you will again get back a `MobileServiceInvalidOperationException` from the service.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, if you attempt to update an untyped item without the "Id" field already set, you will again get back a `MobileServiceInvalidOperationException` from the service.

trans-unit.source: How to: Delete data in a mobile service
trans-unit.target: How to: Delete data in a mobile service

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to delete an existing instance.
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to delete an existing instance.

trans-unit.source: The instance is identified by the "Id" field set on the `todoItem`.
trans-unit.target: The instance is identified by the "Id" field set on the `todoItem`.

trans-unit.source: To delete untyped data, you may take advantage of Json.NET like so.
trans-unit.target: To delete untyped data, you may take advantage of Json.NET like so.

trans-unit.source: Note that when making a delete request, an ID must be specified, as that is how the mobile service identifies which instance to delete.
trans-unit.target: Note that when making a delete request, an ID must be specified, as that is how the mobile service identifies which instance to delete.

trans-unit.source: A delete request needs only the ID; other properties are not passed to the service, and if any are passed, they are ignored at the service.
trans-unit.target: A delete request needs only the ID; other properties are not passed to the service, and if any are passed, they are ignored at the service.

trans-unit.source: The result of a `DeleteAsync` call is usually `null` as well.
trans-unit.target: The result of a `DeleteAsync` call is usually `null` as well.

trans-unit.source: The ID to pass in can be obtained from the result of the `InsertAsync` call.
trans-unit.target: The ID to pass in can be obtained from the result of the `InsertAsync` call.

trans-unit.source: If you attempt to delete an item without the "Id" field already set, there is no way for the service to tell which instance to delete, so you will get back a `MobileServiceInvalidOperationException` from the service.
trans-unit.target: If you attempt to delete an item without the "Id" field already set, there is no way for the service to tell which instance to delete, so you will get back a `MobileServiceInvalidOperationException` from the service.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, if you attempt to delete an untyped item without the "Id" field already set, you will again get back a `MobileServiceInvalidOperationException` from the service.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, if you attempt to delete an untyped item without the "Id" field already set, you will again get back a `MobileServiceInvalidOperationException` from the service.

trans-unit.source: How to: Authenticate users
trans-unit.target: How to: Authenticate users

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services supports authenticating and authorizing app users using a variety of external identity providers: Facebook, Google, Microsoft Account, Twitter, and Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services supports authenticating and authorizing app users using a variety of external identity providers: Facebook, Google, Microsoft Account, Twitter, and Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: You can set permissions on tables to restrict access for specific operations to only authenticated users.
trans-unit.target: You can set permissions on tables to restrict access for specific operations to only authenticated users.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the identity of authenticated users to implement authorization rules in server scripts.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the identity of authenticated users to implement authorization rules in server scripts.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the "Get started with authentication" tutorial ([Xamarin.iOS][Xamarin.iOS authentication]/[Xamarin.Android][Xamarin.Android authentication]).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the "Get started with authentication" tutorial ([Xamarin.iOS][Xamarin.iOS authentication]/[Xamarin.Android][Xamarin.Android authentication]).

trans-unit.source: Two authentication flows are supported: a _server flow_ and a _client flow_.
trans-unit.target: Two authentication flows are supported: a _server flow_ and a _client flow_.

trans-unit.source: The server flow provides the simplest authentication experience, as it relies on the provider's web authentication interface.
trans-unit.target: The server flow provides the simplest authentication experience, as it relies on the provider's web authentication interface.

trans-unit.source: The client flow allows for deeper integration with device-specific capabilities as it relies on provider-specific device-specific SDKs.
trans-unit.target: The client flow allows for deeper integration with device-specific capabilities as it relies on provider-specific device-specific SDKs.

trans-unit.source: Server flow
trans-unit.target: Server flow

trans-unit.source: To have Mobile Services manage the authentication process in your Windows Store or Windows Phone app,
trans-unit.target: To have Mobile Services manage the authentication process in your Windows Store or Windows Phone app,

trans-unit.source: you must register your app with your identity provider.
trans-unit.target: you must register your app with your identity provider.

trans-unit.source: Then in your mobile service, you need to configure the application ID and secret provided by your provider.
trans-unit.target: Then in your mobile service, you need to configure the application ID and secret provided by your provider.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the "Get started with authentication" tutorial ([Xamarin.iOS][Xamarin.iOS authentication]/[Xamarin.Android][Xamarin.Android authentication]).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the "Get started with authentication" tutorial ([Xamarin.iOS][Xamarin.iOS authentication]/[Xamarin.Android][Xamarin.Android authentication]).

trans-unit.source: Once you have registered your identity provider, simply call the [LoginAsync method] with the [MobileServiceAuthenticationProvider] value of your provider.
trans-unit.target: Once you have registered your identity provider, simply call the [LoginAsync method] with the [MobileServiceAuthenticationProvider] value of your provider.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following code initiates a server flow login by using Facebook.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following code initiates a server flow login by using Facebook.

trans-unit.source: If you are using an identity provider other than Facebook, change the value of [MobileServiceAuthenticationProvider] above to the value for your provider.
trans-unit.target: If you are using an identity provider other than Facebook, change the value of [MobileServiceAuthenticationProvider] above to the value for your provider.

trans-unit.source: In this case, Mobile Services manages the OAuth 2.0 authentication flow by displaying the login page of the selected provider and generating a Mobile Services authentication token after successful login with the identity provider.
trans-unit.target: In this case, Mobile Services manages the OAuth 2.0 authentication flow by displaying the login page of the selected provider and generating a Mobile Services authentication token after successful login with the identity provider.

trans-unit.source: The [LoginAsync method] returns a [MobileServiceUser], which provides both the [userId] of the authenticated user and the [MobileServiceAuthenticationToken], as a JSON web token (JWT).
trans-unit.target: The [LoginAsync method] returns a [MobileServiceUser], which provides both the [userId] of the authenticated user and the [MobileServiceAuthenticationToken], as a JSON web token (JWT).

trans-unit.source: This token can be cached and re-used until it expires.
trans-unit.target: This token can be cached and re-used until it expires.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Caching the authentication token].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Caching the authentication token].

trans-unit.source: Client flow
trans-unit.target: Client flow

trans-unit.source: Your app can also independently contact the identity provider and then provide the returned token to Mobile Services for authentication.
trans-unit.target: Your app can also independently contact the identity provider and then provide the returned token to Mobile Services for authentication.

trans-unit.source: This client flow enables you to provide a single sign-in experience for users or to retrieve additional user data from the identity provider.
trans-unit.target: This client flow enables you to provide a single sign-in experience for users or to retrieve additional user data from the identity provider.

trans-unit.source: In the most simplified form, you can use the client flow as shown in this snippet for Facebook or Google.
trans-unit.target: In the most simplified form, you can use the client flow as shown in this snippet for Facebook or Google.

trans-unit.source: Caching the authentication token
trans-unit.target: Caching the authentication token

trans-unit.source: In some cases, the call to the login method can be avoided after the first time the user authenticates.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, the call to the login method can be avoided after the first time the user authenticates.

trans-unit.source: You can use a local secure store (such as [Xamarin.Auth][Xamarin.Auth component]) to cache the current user identity the first time they log in and every subsequent time you check whether you already have the user identity in our cache.
trans-unit.target: You can use a local secure store (such as [Xamarin.Auth][Xamarin.Auth component]) to cache the current user identity the first time they log in and every subsequent time you check whether you already have the user identity in our cache.

trans-unit.source: When the cache is empty, you still need to send the user through the login process.
trans-unit.target: When the cache is empty, you still need to send the user through the login process.

trans-unit.source: How to: Handle errors
trans-unit.target: How to: Handle errors

trans-unit.source: There are several ways to encounter, validate, and work around errors in Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: There are several ways to encounter, validate, and work around errors in Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: As an example, server scripts are registered in a mobile service and can be used to perform a wide range of operations on data being inserted and updated, including validation and data modification.
trans-unit.target: As an example, server scripts are registered in a mobile service and can be used to perform a wide range of operations on data being inserted and updated, including validation and data modification.

trans-unit.source: Imagine defining and registering a server script that validate and modify data, like so:
trans-unit.target: Imagine defining and registering a server script that validate and modify data, like so:

trans-unit.source: This server-side script validates the length of string data sent to the mobile service and rejects strings that are too long, in this case longer than 10 characters.
trans-unit.target: This server-side script validates the length of string data sent to the mobile service and rejects strings that are too long, in this case longer than 10 characters.

trans-unit.source: Now that the mobile service is validating data and sending error responses on the server-side, you can update your .NET app to be able to handle error responses from validation.
trans-unit.target: Now that the mobile service is validating data and sending error responses on the server-side, you can update your .NET app to be able to handle error responses from validation.

trans-unit.source: How to: Work with untyped data
trans-unit.target: How to: Work with untyped data

trans-unit.source: The Xamarin Component client is designed for strongly typed scenarios.
trans-unit.target: The Xamarin Component client is designed for strongly typed scenarios.

trans-unit.source: However, sometimes, a more loosely typed experience is convenient; for example, this could be when dealing with objects with open schema.
trans-unit.target: However, sometimes, a more loosely typed experience is convenient; for example, this could be when dealing with objects with open schema.

trans-unit.source: That scenario is enabled as follows.
trans-unit.target: That scenario is enabled as follows.

trans-unit.source: In queries, you forego LINQ and use the wire format.
trans-unit.target: In queries, you forego LINQ and use the wire format.

trans-unit.source: You get back JSON values that you can use like a property bag.
trans-unit.target: You get back JSON values that you can use like a property bag.

trans-unit.source: For more information on JToken and Json.NET, see [Json.NET](http://json.codeplex.com/)
trans-unit.target: For more information on JToken and Json.NET, see [Json.NET](http://json.codeplex.com/)

trans-unit.source: How to: Design unit tests
trans-unit.target: How to: Design unit tests

trans-unit.source: The value returned by `MobileServiceClient.GetTable` and the queries are interfaces.
trans-unit.target: The value returned by `MobileServiceClient.GetTable` and the queries are interfaces.

trans-unit.source: That makes them easily "mockable" for testing purposes, so you could create a `MyMockTable : IMobileServiceTable<TodoItem>` that implements your testing logic.
trans-unit.target: That makes them easily "mockable" for testing purposes, so you could create a `MyMockTable : IMobileServiceTable<TodoItem>` that implements your testing logic.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: Now that you have completed this how-to conceptual reference topic, learn how to perform important tasks in Mobile Services in detail:
trans-unit.target: Now that you have completed this how-to conceptual reference topic, learn how to perform important tasks in Mobile Services in detail:

trans-unit.source: Get started with Mobile Services ([Xamarin.iOS][Get started with Mobile Services iOS]/[Xamarin.Android][Get started with Mobile Services Android])
trans-unit.target: Get started with Mobile Services ([Xamarin.iOS][Get started with Mobile Services iOS]/[Xamarin.Android][Get started with Mobile Services Android])

trans-unit.source: Learn the basics of how to use Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Learn the basics of how to use Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: Get started with data ([Xamarin.iOS][Get started with data iOS]/[Xamarin.Android][Get started with data Android])
trans-unit.target: Get started with data ([Xamarin.iOS][Get started with data iOS]/[Xamarin.Android][Get started with data Android])

trans-unit.source: Learn more about storing and querying data using Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Learn more about storing and querying data using Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: Get started with authentication ([Xamarin.iOS][Get started with authentication iOS]/[Xamarin.Android][Get started with authentication Android])
trans-unit.target: Get started with authentication ([Xamarin.iOS][Get started with authentication iOS]/[Xamarin.Android][Get started with authentication Android])

trans-unit.source: Learn how to authenticate users of your app with an identity provider.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to authenticate users of your app with an identity provider.

trans-unit.source: Validate and modify data with scripts ([Xamarin.iOS][Validate and modify data with scripts ios]/[Xamarin.Android][Validate and modify data with scripts android])
trans-unit.target: Validate and modify data with scripts ([Xamarin.iOS][Validate and modify data with scripts ios]/[Xamarin.Android][Validate and modify data with scripts android])

trans-unit.source: Learn more about using server scripts in Mobile Services to validate and change data sent from your app.
trans-unit.target: Learn more about using server scripts in Mobile Services to validate and change data sent from your app.

trans-unit.source: Refine queries with paging ([Xamarin.iOS][Refine queries with paging iOS]/[Xamarin.Android][Refine queries with paging Android])
trans-unit.target: Refine queries with paging ([Xamarin.iOS][Refine queries with paging iOS]/[Xamarin.Android][Refine queries with paging Android])

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use paging in queries to control the amount of data handled in a single request.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use paging in queries to control the amount of data handled in a single request.

trans-unit.source: Authorize users with scripts ([Xamarin.iOS][Authorize users with scripts iOS]/[Xamarin.Android][Authorize users with scripts Android])
trans-unit.target: Authorize users with scripts ([Xamarin.iOS][Authorize users with scripts iOS]/[Xamarin.Android][Authorize users with scripts Android])

trans-unit.source: Learn how to take the user ID value provided by Mobile Services based on an authenticated user and use it to filter the data returned by Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to take the user ID value provided by Mobile Services based on an authenticated user and use it to filter the data returned by Mobile Services.
